title: George Reed (Canadian football)
text:
George Robert Reed, <a href="Order%20of%20Canada">CM</a>, <a href="Saskatchewan%20Order%20of%20Merit">SOM</a> (born October 2, 1939), is a former American <a href="college%20football">college football</a> and <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">Canadian Football League</a> player. Reed, along with <a href="Mike%20Pringle%20%28gridiron%20football%29">Mike Pringle</a> and <a href="Johnny%20Bright">Johnny Bright</a>, is one of the players most often mentioned as being the greatest <a href="running%20back">running back</a> in CFL history. In November 2006, Reed was voted one of the CFL's <a href="TSN%20Top%2050%20CFL%20Players">Top 50 players</a> (#2) of the league's modern era by Canadian sports network <a href="The%20Sports%20Network">TSN</a>.
Reed played his entire 13-year professional football career for the <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">CFL</a> <a href="Saskatchewan%20Roughriders">Saskatchewan Roughriders</a> and his #34 <a href="Jersey%20%28clothing%29">jersey</a> is one of eight that has been <a href="Saskatchewan%20Roughriders%23Retired%20numbers">retired</a> by the club.
His daughter <a href="Georgette%20Reed">Georgette</a> represented Canada in the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20shot%20put">1992 Summer Olympics</a> in the shot put competition.
College career.
Reed played <a href="Pacific-8%20Conference">Pacific-8 Conference</a> college football with the <a href="Washington%20State%20University">Washington State University</a> Cougars from 1959 to 1962 where he was teamed with fellow Canadian Football Hall of Famer <a href="Hugh%20Campbell">Hugh Campbell</a>.
CFL.
Following college, Reed signed with the <a href="Saskatchewan%20Roughriders">Saskatchewan Roughriders</a> where he starred for 13 years from <a href="1963%20CFL%20season">1963</a> until <a href="1975%20CFL%20season">1975</a>, 203 games in all. By the time he retired, Reed held career <a href="CFL%20records">records</a> in rushing yards (16,116), rushing <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s (134), and touchdowns (137). Reed's rushing yards total has since been surpassed by <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> stars <a href="Emmitt%20Smith">Emmitt Smith</a> and <a href="Walter%20Payton">Walter Payton</a>, and, in <a href="2004%20CFL%20season">2004</a> by <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">CFL</a> star <a href="Mike%20Pringle%20%28Canadian%20football%29">Mike Pringle</a>. Pringle tied Reed's total of 137 career touchdowns, and George Reed still holds the CFL rushing for touchdowns record with 134.
George Reed was voted the <a href="CFL%27s%20Outstanding%20Player%20Award">CFL's Most Outstanding Player</a> for <a href="1965%20CFL%20season">1965</a> and in <a href="1976%20CFL%20season">1976</a> he was the inaugural winner of the <a href="Tom%20Pate%20Memorial%20Award">Tom Pate Memorial Trophy</a> for playing ability and <a href="community%20service">community service</a>. He was the MVP of the <a href="54th%20Grey%20Cup">54th Grey Cup</a> of 1966, as Saskatchewan defeated Ottawa, his sole Grey Cup win.
On October 9, 1973, in <a href="Regina%2C%20Saskatchewan">Regina, Saskatchewan</a>, George Reed was honored with the unique proclamation of October 9 as George Reed Day.
In 1972, while still an active player, Reed became the fourth president of the <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League%20Players%27%20Association">Canadian Football League Players' Association</a> (CFLPA). He maintained the CFLPA presidency until 1981, six years after his retirement from the CFL. Reed returned as the sixth president of the CFLPA from 1986 to 1993.
Post-football career.
A naturalized Canadian citizen who is currently the Director of Guest and Community Relations at SaskGaming, Reed was made a Member of the <a href="Order%20of%20Canada">Order of Canada</a> in 1978, Canada's highest civilian honour, and in 1979 was inducted into the <a href="Canadian%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Canadian Football Hall of Fame</a>.
He is the father of <a href="Georgette%20Reed">Georgette Reed</a> who represented Canada in the women's shot put at the 1992 Summer Olympics.
In 2012 in honour of the <a href="100th%20Grey%20Cup">100th Grey Cup</a>, <a href="Canada%20Post">Canada Post</a> used his image on a series of commemorative postage stamps. The image was also used on presentation posters and other materials to promote the Grey Cup game and other celebrations associated with the centennial.
